message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of HbA and elevated HbA2 suggests β-thalassemia, and the crewcut appearance on skull X-ray is a classic finding in β-thalassemia major. The patient’s symptoms suggest that it is β-thalassemia major and not β-thalassemia minor or α-thalassemia trait. Hb Bart disease is associated with α-thalassemia, not β-thalassemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of HbA and the elevated HbA2 levels indicate β-thalassemia major. The crewcut appearance on skull X-ray is due to expansion of bone marrow from increased erythropoiesis. Hb Bart disease is seen in α-thalassemia, which is not indicated here. β-thal minor would have normal HbA levels. Alpha thal trait would have normal HbA and HbF levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of microcytic anemia, elevated HbA2, and absence of HbA suggests β-thal major, also known as Cooley's anemia. Crewcut appearance is also a characteristic finding in β-thal major. Other options have different clinical presentations: α-thal trait has no clinical symptoms, Hb Bart disease usually presents in infants and has severe symptoms, and β-thal minor typically presents with mild symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of HbA and elevated HbA2 levels are characteristic of β-thalassemia, and the crewcut appearance on the skull X-ray suggests severe anemia caused by β-thal major. Options A and D are unlikely because they do not result in the absence of HbA, and Hb Bart disease presents with hydrops fetalis and is fatal in the majority of cases.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of HbA, elevated HbA2, normal HbF, and the crewcut appearance on skull X-ray are all indicative of β-thal major, which is the most likely diagnosis. α-thal trait and β-thal minor would not cause the same degree of anemia while Hb Bart disease is associated with hydrops fetalis and is not typically seen in a 13-year-old.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of HbA and microcytic anemia suggests β-thal major. Elevated HbA2 is also seen in β-thal minor but not to the extent of β-thal major. α-thal trait does not result in microcytic anemia and Hb Bart disease would result in elevated levels of Hb Bart and HbH, not just HbA2. The crewcut appearance on the skull X-ray is secondary to extramedullary hematopoiesis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of HbA and elevated HbA2 suggest β-thalassemia. The crewcut appearance on X-ray is due to skull expansion as a result of increased erythropoiesis. Hb Bart disease is associated with α-thalassemia, which is not indicated in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of adult hemoglobin and presence of elevated HbA2 and normal HbF indicate β-thalassemia. The crewcut appearance on the skull X-ray also supports this diagnosis. Option B, Hb Bart disease, is associated with alpha-thalassemia and options A and D are traits rather than a disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The microcytic anemia, elevated HbA2, and crewcut appearance on X-ray suggest β-thal major. Hb Bart disease would have shown a hydrops fetalis with no HbA or HbA2. α-thal trait or β-thal minor would not have presented with such severe symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of HbA and elevated HbA2 suggest β-thalassemia. The crew-cut appearance on the X-ray suggests increased erythropoiesis due to chronic anemia. Hb Bart disease is associated with α-thalassemia, and α-thal trait usually does not cause significant symptoms. β-thal minor does not usually cause microcytic anemia.
